title: Reversible Cerebral Vasoconstriction Syndrome (RCVS)
scope: ** Diagnosis, acute management, and follow-up of RCVS in adults. Covers thunderclap headache evaluation, vasoconstrictor identification and withdrawal, calcium channel blocker therapy, blood pressure management, monitoring for complications (convexity SAH, ischemic stroke, PRES overlap), and serial imaging to document resolution. Excludes primary CNS vasculitis (PACNS — separate evaluation), aneurysmal SAH, and isolated thunderclap headache without vasoconstriction.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline; rule out infection or thrombocytopenia; pre-procedure assessment
Electrolytes; renal function for contrast imaging; hepatic function
Differentiate from CNS vasculitis (PACNS) — ESR is typically NORMAL in RCVS; elevated ESR favors vasculitis
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal (elevated suggests alternative diagnosis such as PACNS)

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Differentiate from CNS vasculitis — CRP is typically NORMAL in RCVS; elevated CRP favors vasculitis
Postpartum RCVS is a major trigger; pregnancy affects treatment options
Cannabis, cocaine, amphetamines, and other sympathomimetics are common RCVS triggers
Thyroid dysfunction as headache contributor; baseline before treatment
Low magnesium may exacerbate vasospasm; correct before CCB therapy
Neurogenic cardiac injury; stress cardiomyopathy with severe hypertension

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Screen for systemic autoimmune disease if vasculitis differential remains
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis and other ANCA-associated vasculitides causing cerebral vasculitis
Syphilitic meningitis/vasculitis can mimic RCVS on angiography
Identify specific sympathomimetic agents (cocaine, amphetamines, ecstasy, pseudoephedrine); serotonergic drugs
Pheochromocytoma can cause hypertensive crisis with thunderclap headache and vasoconstriction

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.item: Hypercoagulable panel (protein C, S, antithrombin III, Factor V Leiden)
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: If ischemic stroke complication; atypical presentation
Intravascular lymphoma or leptomeningeal disease mimicking vasoconstriction
Familial or recurrent RCVS; collagen vascular disorders predisposing to cerebral vasculopathy

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Elevated in SAH, IIH; typically normal in RCVS
SAH (RBC non-clearing); meningitis (WBC); RCVS typically <10 WBC. WBC >10 strongly suggests PACNS or infection
Lumbar Puncture.target: WBC <5; RBC 0 or clearing (RCVS: normal or minimal pleocytosis <10 WBC)

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Elevated in vasculitis, infection; RCVS typically normal or mildly elevated (<60 mg/dL). Protein >60 suggests PACNS
Low CSF glucose suggests infection; normal in RCVS and PACNS
Rule out SAH if CT negative; present if prior subarachnoid bleeding
Exclude bacterial meningitis (meningismus overlap with thunderclap headache)
Leptomeningeal carcinomatosis causing vessel encasement and secondary vasoconstriction

Essential/First-line.timing: IMMEDIATE — rule out hemorrhage (convexity SAH in ~30% of RCVS); parenchymal hemorrhage; large territory infarct
Essential/First-line.target: Convexity SAH (non-aneurysmal pattern over convexities, NOT in basal cisterns); may be normal early

Essential/First-line.timing: Simultaneously with non-contrast CT; first-line vascular imaging for RCVS
Essential/First-line.target: Multifocal segmental narrowing ("string of beads" pattern) of large and medium cerebral arteries; alternating areas of constriction and dilation
Essential/First-line.contraindications: Contrast allergy (premedicate); renal impairment (benefit outweighs risk in acute setting)

Essential/First-line.timing: Within 24 hours of presentation; superior to CT for detecting ischemic stroke, PRES, and edema
Essential/First-line.target: Cortical SAH on FLAIR/GRE; PRES (posterior white matter vasogenic edema); DWI restriction (watershed infarcts); convexity hemorrhage on SWI

Essential/First-line.timing: With MRI; non-invasive vascular assessment without contrast
Essential/First-line.target: Multifocal segmental narrowing; "string of beads"; may underestimate vasoconstriction compared to DSA

Essential/First-line.timing: At presentation; baseline before calcium channel blocker therapy
Essential/First-line.target: Normal baseline; rule out QT prolongation; arrhythmia; ischemic changes

Extended.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (CPT 70553)
Extended.timing: If concern for vasculitis (vessel wall enhancement); PRES confirmation
Extended.target: RCVS: NO vessel wall enhancement (key differentiator from PACNS). PRES: posterior white matter edema without enhancement

Extended.timing: When available; distinguish RCVS from PACNS definitively
Extended.target: RCVS: smooth narrowing WITHOUT concentric vessel wall enhancement. PACNS: concentric vessel wall enhancement (gadolinium)

Extended.timing: GOLD STANDARD for cerebral vasoconstriction; if CTA/MRA equivocal or PACNS cannot be excluded; also allows provocative testing
Extended.target: "String of beads" — multifocal segmental narrowing and dilation affecting multiple vascular territories bilaterally; smooth tapering
Extended.contraindications: Contrast allergy; coagulopathy; renal impairment; procedural risk (~0.5-1% stroke)

Extended.timing: Non-invasive bedside monitoring; serial studies to track vasoconstriction evolution
Extended.target: Elevated mean flow velocities in affected arteries (MCA >120 cm/s suggests vasospasm); velocities normalize as RCVS resolves over 4-12 weeks
Extended.contraindications: Absent temporal bone window (~10% of patients)

Extended.timing: If clinical suspicion for ischemic complication (new focal deficit)
Extended.target: Perfusion deficits in watershed distributions; mismatch (penumbra — potentially salvageable)

Extended.timing: If cardiac murmur, cardiac biomarker elevation, or PFO/embolic source evaluation
Extended.target: Normal; rule out Takotsubo; PFO evaluation

Rare/Specialized.timing: At 8-12 weeks from onset; confirmatory diagnostic criterion
Rare/Specialized.target: COMPLETE RESOLUTION of previously seen vasoconstriction — confirms RCVS diagnosis (reversibility is the defining feature)

Rare/Specialized.item: Follow-up CTA or MRA (4-6 week interim)
Rare/Specialized.timing: At 4-6 weeks; interim assessment of vasoconstriction trajectory
Rare/Specialized.target: Improving or resolving vasoconstriction; persistent constriction warrants continued treatment

Rare/Specialized.timing: Research/atypical cases; functional assessment of perfusion deficits
ONLY if PACNS remains the leading diagnosis despite non-invasive workup; avoid if RCVS is strongly suspected
Rare/Specialized.target: Vasculitis: vessel wall inflammation, granulomata. RCVS: normal biopsy

Acute/Emergent.indication: CORNERSTONE OF RCVS MANAGEMENT — removal of the inciting trigger

dosing.instructions: Immediately discontinue ALL vasoconstrictors: triptans, ergotamine, cocaine, amphetamines, cannabis, pseudoephedrine, SSRIs/SNRIs (taper if on chronic therapy to avoid withdrawal), nasal decongestants, diet pills, energy supplements. Document complete medication reconciliation

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Abrupt SSRI/SNRI discontinuation may cause withdrawal syndrome — taper over 1-2 weeks if on chronic therapy
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Review medication list daily; urine drug screen to confirm compliance

Acute/Emergent.indication: Calcium channel blocker to reduce cerebral vasoconstriction and prevent recurrent thunderclap headache

dosing.instructions: Start 80 mg PO TID; titrate to 120 mg TID (or 240 mg SR BID) over 3-5 days based on BP tolerance; max 480 mg/day; continue for 4-12 weeks until imaging resolution

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Heart block (2nd/3rd degree AV block); severe LV dysfunction (EF <30%); sick sinus syndrome; concurrent beta-blocker use (risk of severe bradycardia/hypotension); SBP <90
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: ECG before starting and at 48-72h; BP and HR q4-6h during titration; continuous telemetry first 24h inpatient

Acute/Emergent.indication: Calcium channel blocker with preferential cerebral vascular selectivity; alternative to verapamil

dosing.instructions: 60 mg PO q4h (or 30 mg q2h if hypotension); continue for 4-12 weeks until imaging resolution; do NOT give IV (severe hypotension)

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Hypotension (SBP <90 — reduce to 30 mg q2h); hepatic impairment (reduce dose)
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: BP with each dose; enteral route ONLY (never IV); may cause hypotension especially in first 24-48h

Acute/Emergent.indication: Severe hypertension (SBP >180) in acute RCVS — IV nicardipine provides precise BP control; dual benefit as CCB for vasoconstriction

doseOptions.orderSentence: Blood pressure control: Nicardipine IV 5 mg/h IV

dosing.instructions: 5 mg/h IV infusion; titrate by 2.5 mg/h q5-15min; max 15 mg/h. Target SBP 120-160 mmHg; avoid aggressive BP lowering below 120 (risk of watershed ischemia from vasoconstriction)
dosing.orderSentence: Blood pressure control: Nicardipine IV 5 mg/h IV

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Continuous arterial BP monitoring; neuro checks q1h

Acute/Emergent.indication: Severe hypertension (SBP >180) when CCB alone insufficient or not yet started

doseOptions.orderSentence: Blood pressure control: Labetalol IV 20 mg IV

dosing.instructions: 10-20 mg IV push q10-20min; max 300 mg. Target SBP 120-160 mmHg
dosing.orderSentence: Blood pressure control: Labetalol IV 20 mg IV

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Heart block; severe bradycardia; asthma; decompensated CHF

Acute/Emergent.indication: Maintain euvolemia to prevent worsening of vasoconstriction-related ischemia; dehydration may exacerbate vasospasm

dosing.instructions: NS at 75-125 mL/h; titrate to maintain euvolemia; avoid both hypovolemia and fluid overload

Acute/Emergent.indication: Correct hypomagnesemia; magnesium has vasodilatory properties and may reduce vasospasm

dosing.instructions: 2-4 g IV over 1-2h if Mg <2.0; target serum Mg >2.0 mg/dL; maintenance 1-2 g IV q6h if persistently low

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Serum Mg q12-24h; deep tendon reflexes

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Analgesic for thunderclap headache — first-line because it does NOT cause vasoconstriction; avoid all triptans and ergotamines

dosing.instructions: 1000 mg PO q6h PRN headache; max 4000 mg/day (3000 mg/day if hepatic impairment). IV: 1000 mg IV q6h PRN if NPO

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: NSAID for severe thunderclap headache refractory to acetaminophen; short-course only

dosing.instructions: 30 mg IV x1, then 15-30 mg IV q6h PRN; max 5 days total; reduce to 15 mg in elderly or renal impairment

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Active GI bleeding; renal impairment (CrCl <30); coagulopathy; concurrent anticoagulation; known SAH with active bleeding risk

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: NSAID for outpatient headache management after discharge; avoid in patients with SAH complication

dosing.instructions: 400-600 mg PO q6-8h PRN; max 2400 mg/day; take with food

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: GI bleeding; renal impairment; concurrent anticoagulation; known intracranial hemorrhage

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Antiemetic for nausea/vomiting associated with thunderclap headache

dosing.instructions: 4 mg IV/PO q6-8h PRN nausea; max 16 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Antiemetic with mild analgesic properties for headache-associated nausea

dosing.instructions: 10 mg IV q8h PRN nausea; give with diphenhydramine 25 mg to prevent akathisia

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Parkinsonism; seizure history; bowel obstruction; pheochromocytoma

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Anxiolysis and headache relief; reduces sympathetic drive which may worsen vasoconstriction

dosing.instructions: 0.5-1 mg IV/PO q6-8h PRN severe headache or anxiety; short-course only (3-5 days)

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Respiratory depression; severe hepatic impairment; concurrent CNS depressants

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Stool softener to prevent straining/Valsalva which may trigger thunderclap headache recurrence

dosing.instructions: 100 mg PO BID while symptomatic; Valsalva is a common trigger for RCVS thunderclap headaches

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Refractory vasoconstriction with progressive neurologic deficits despite oral CCB therapy

doseOptions.orderSentence: Verapamil (IV loading — refractory cases) 5 mg IV

dosing.instructions: 5 mg IV over 2 min; may repeat q15min x3; max 20 mg; then transition to oral verapamil. Use with continuous cardiac monitoring
dosing.orderSentence: Verapamil (IV loading — refractory cases) 5 mg IV

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Complete heart block; severe LV dysfunction; concurrent IV beta-blocker; SBP <90
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Continuous telemetry; BP q5min during infusion; ECG for PR prolongation

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Persistent thunderclap headaches or worsening vasoconstriction on standard dose

dosing.instructions: Increase from 60 mg to 90 mg PO q4h; monitor BP closely; max 540 mg/day; higher doses increase hypotension risk

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: BP q2h during escalation; hepatic function

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Severe, progressive vasoconstriction with ischemic deficit refractory to oral/IV therapy — endovascular rescue

dosing.instructions: Verapamil 5-10 mg intra-arterial per vessel during cerebral angiography; may repeat in multiple territories; performed by neurointerventionalist

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Angiographic response; clinical improvement; BP during procedure

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Severe, progressive vasoconstriction with ischemic deficit refractory to oral/IV therapy — alternative to IA verapamil

dosing.instructions: Nicardipine 5-10 mg intra-arterial per vessel during cerebral angiography

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Focal severe proximal vasoconstriction causing critical ischemia; refractory to pharmacologic vasodilation

dosing.instructions: Mechanical dilation of severely spastic proximal cerebral arteries during angiography

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Vessel rupture risk; distal vasoconstriction not amenable to balloon; diffuse disease

Second-line/Refractory.item: Methylprednisolone IV (if PRES overlap with edema)
Second-line/Refractory.indication: PRES-type cerebral edema with seizures or encephalopathy overlapping with RCVS; NOT standard for uncomplicated RCVS

doseOptions.orderSentence: Methylprednisolone IV (if PRES overlap with edema) 1000 mg IV

dosing.instructions: 500-1000 mg IV daily for 3-5 days; infuse over 1 hour. Use ONLY for PRES overlap with significant edema; steroids are NOT routinely recommended for RCVS and may worsen outcomes if PACNS is misdiagnosed
dosing.orderSentence: Methylprednisolone IV (if PRES overlap with edema) 1000 mg IV

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Active infection; poorly controlled diabetes; GI bleeding
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Blood glucose q6h; BP; infection signs; psychiatric effects

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Seizure prophylaxis or treatment if seizures occur (more common with PRES overlap or cortical SAH)

dosing.instructions: Load 1000-1500 mg IV, then 500-1000 mg BID; adjust for renal function

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Seizure monitoring; renal function; mood/behavior changes

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.indication: Ongoing CCB therapy during recovery phase; continue until imaging confirms resolution of vasoconstriction at 8-12 weeks

dosing.instructions: Maintain effective dose (typically 240-480 mg/day as 80-120 mg TID or 240 mg SR BID) for 8-12 weeks; taper gradually over 2-4 weeks once follow-up CTA/MRA shows complete resolution

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.pretreatment: ECG (assess PR interval); renal and hepatic function
Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.contraindications: Heart block; severe LV dysfunction; concurrent beta-blocker
Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.monitoring: ECG at baseline and q2-4 weeks during taper; BP at each visit; repeat CTA/MRA at 8-12 weeks

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.indication: Alternative to verapamil for ongoing CCB therapy during recovery phase

dosing.instructions: Continue 60 mg PO q4h for 8-12 weeks; taper by reducing frequency to q6h then q8h over 2-4 weeks once imaging confirms resolution

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.pretreatment: Hepatic function (dose reduce in hepatic impairment)
Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.monitoring: BP with dose changes; hepatic function; follow-up CTA/MRA at 8-12 weeks

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.indication: Long-acting CCB for patients transitioning from verapamil or nimodipine; easier compliance for outpatient management; also provides BP control

doseOptions.orderSentence: Amlodipine (transition to long-acting CCB) 5 mg PO

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg PO daily; increase to 10 mg daily as needed; may use as transition from verapamil/nimodipine for longer-term management
dosing.orderSentence: Amlodipine (transition to long-acting CCB) 5 mg PO

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.monitoring: BP; pedal edema; repeat CTA/MRA at 8-12 weeks

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology consult for RCVS diagnosis confirmation, vasoconstrictor identification, and CCB management
Neurocritical care if ischemic stroke, significant SAH, or PRES with seizures requiring ICU-level monitoring
Neurointerventional radiology if progressive vasoconstriction with ischemic deficits refractory to medical management (intra-arterial vasodilator or angioplasty)
Headache specialist (neurology) for long-term headache management and migraine prophylaxis after RCVS resolution, as migraine is a common comorbidity
Psychiatry consultation if vasoconstrictor exposure was illicit drug use (cocaine, amphetamines, cannabis) requiring addiction medicine support
Obstetrics/MFM consultation if postpartum RCVS for future pregnancy counseling and breastfeeding-safe medication review
Pharmacy consultation for complete medication reconciliation to identify all potential vasoconstrictors including OTC and herbal supplements
Physical therapy for gait assessment and fall prevention if focal deficits from stroke complication
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment and cognitive rehabilitation if ischemic stroke complication
Speech-language pathology for swallow and language evaluation if stroke complication affects dominant hemisphere or brainstem

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately or call 911 if sudden severe headache recurs, new weakness or numbness develops, vision changes, difficulty speaking, or seizure occurs (may indicate stroke complication from ongoing vasoconstriction)

AVOID all known triggers: do NOT use triptans, ergotamine, cocaine, amphetamines, cannabis, excessive caffeine, pseudoephedrine/phenylephrine nasal decongestants, or energy supplements — these may worsen vasoconstriction and cause stroke
Avoid Valsalva maneuvers (heavy lifting, straining at stool, vigorous exercise) for 4-6 weeks as these commonly trigger recurrent thunderclap headaches in RCVS
Avoid very hot showers or baths (bath-related thunderclap headache is a recognized RCVS trigger)
Avoid sexual activity during acute phase (2-4 weeks) as orgasm-related headache is a common RCVS trigger
Take calcium channel blocker medication exactly as prescribed; do not stop suddenly without physician guidance
Do NOT drive until cleared by neurology due to risk of sudden severe headache or stroke while operating a vehicle
Report any new medications (including OTC, herbals, and supplements) to your neurologist before starting, as many common medications can trigger vasoconstriction
RCVS typically resolves completely within 12 weeks — follow-up imaging will confirm resolution and guide medication taper

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Complete cessation of all illicit drug use (cocaine, amphetamines, cannabis, ecstasy/MDMA) — these are among the strongest RCVS triggers
Avoid all vasoconstrictor medications long-term including triptans, ergotamine, and sympathomimetic decongestants — provide patient with written list of medications to avoid
Blood pressure control target <130/80 mmHg to reduce risk of hemorrhagic and ischemic complications
Smoking cessation to reduce vascular risk and improve endothelial function
Caffeine moderation (limit to <200 mg/day) as excessive caffeine may contribute to vasoconstriction
Stress management and sleep hygiene as physiological stress and sleep deprivation may lower the threshold for vasoconstriction
Graduated return to exercise starting with light activity (walking, yoga) after 4-6 weeks; avoid heavy resistance training until imaging confirms resolution
If postpartum RCVS: discuss recurrence risk with neurologist before future pregnancies; recurrence rate is low (~5-10%) but higher with re-exposure to triggers

differential.features: Progressive headache over weeks (NOT thunderclap); CSF abnormal (pleocytosis >10 WBC, elevated protein >60); vessel wall enhancement on MRI VWI; ESR/CRP often elevated; does NOT resolve spontaneously; requires immunosuppression
differential.tests: CSF analysis (abnormal in PACNS, normal in RCVS); MRI VWI (concentric enhancement in PACNS, absent in RCVS); ESR/CRP (elevated in PACNS); brain biopsy (granulomatous inflammation)

differential.features: Blood in BASAL CISTERNS (not convexities); aneurysm on CTA/DSA; single thunderclap event; Hunt-Hess grading; requires aneurysm securing
differential.tests: CT (cisternal blood pattern); CTA (aneurysm identified); DSA (gold standard); LP (xanthochromia if CT negative)

differential.features: May overlap with RCVS (10-40% co-occurrence); seizures and encephalopathy more prominent; bilateral posterior white matter edema on MRI; associated with hypertension, eclampsia, immunosuppressants
differential.tests: MRI (posterior-dominant vasogenic edema); clinical context (hypertension, eclampsia); RCVS and PRES frequently coexist

differential.features: Gradual onset aura (over 5-60 min); headache builds over minutes-hours (NOT thunderclap peaking in <60 sec); recurrent stereotyped episodes; normal vascular imaging
differential.tests: Clinical history (gradual onset vs thunderclap); CTA/MRA (normal in migraine; "string of beads" in RCVS)

differential.features: Subacute headache over days; papilledema; seizures; hemorrhagic venous infarcts; risk factors (OCPs, pregnancy, coagulopathy); thrombosed sinus on MRV
differential.tests: MRV or CT venogram (sinus thrombosis); D-dimer (may be elevated); CSF (elevated pressure)

differential.features: Neck pain with ipsilateral headache; Horner syndrome; ischemic stroke in single vascular territory (NOT multifocal); intimal flap on CTA
differential.tests: CTA/MRA neck (intimal flap, pseudoaneurysm, mural hematoma); MRI neck with fat sat (crescent sign)

differential.features: Sudden headache with visual field defect and ophthalmoplegia; known pituitary adenoma; hemorrhage/infarction within pituitary gland
differential.tests: MRI sella (hemorrhagic/infarcted pituitary mass); hormone panel (panhypopituitarism); visual fields

differential.features: Orthostatic headache (worse upright, better supine); may have thunderclap onset; diffuse pachymeningeal enhancement; brain sagging on MRI
differential.tests: MRI (diffuse pachymeningeal enhancement, brain sagging, subdural fluid); LP (low opening pressure <6 cm H2O)

differential.features: Severely elevated BP (>220/120); headache; may have PRES features; no segmental vasoconstriction on vascular imaging
differential.tests: CTA/MRA (no "string of beads"); MRI (may show PRES); BP response to treatment

differential.features: Paroxysmal hypertension with headache, palpitations, diaphoresis; episodic; adrenal mass
differential.tests: Serum/urine catecholamines and metanephrines; CT/MRI abdomen (adrenal mass)

evidence.recommendation: Thunderclap headache as hallmark presentation; recurrent thunderclap headaches over 1-4 weeks are pathognomonic for RCVS
evidence.source: [Ducros et al. Brain 2007](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18025032/) — largest prospective cohort (67 patients); defined clinical spectrum

evidence.recommendation: Vasoconstrictor exposure identification and withdrawal as cornerstone of management
evidence.source: [Ducros & Bousser. Lancet Neurol 2012](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22995694/) — comprehensive review of triggers and management

evidence.recommendation: CTA/MRA as first-line vascular imaging; "string of beads" pattern; may be normal early
evidence.source: [Chen et al. Cephalalgia 2010](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19614685/) — CTA sensitivity and serial imaging findings

evidence.recommendation: Calcium channel blockers (verapamil, nimodipine) as mainstay therapy
evidence.source: [Ducros et al. Brain 2007](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18025032/); [Singhal et al. Neurology 2011](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21601163/) — observational data; no RCTs available

evidence.recommendation: Verapamil preferred first-line CCB for RCVS
evidence.source: [Singhal & Bernstein. Neurocrit Care 2005](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/16159105/) — early description of verapamil use; expert consensus

evidence.recommendation: Nimodipine as alternative CCB with cerebrovascular selectivity
evidence.source: [Calabrese et al. Ann Intern Med 2007](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17200220/) — narrative review and recommendations

evidence.recommendation: Resolution of vasoconstriction within 12 weeks confirms diagnosis
evidence.source: [Ducros et al. Brain 2007](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18025032/) — resolution documented by serial angiography

evidence.recommendation: Convexity SAH occurs in ~30% of RCVS patients
evidence.source: [Ducros et al. Stroke 2010](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20884871/) — hemorrhagic and ischemic complications of RCVS

evidence.recommendation: CSF is typically normal in RCVS (distinguishes from PACNS)
evidence.source: [Ducros et al. Brain 2007](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18025032/); [Calabrese et al. Ann Intern Med 2007](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17200220/)

evidence.recommendation: MRI vessel wall imaging differentiates RCVS (no enhancement) from PACNS (concentric enhancement)
evidence.source: [Mandell et al. Stroke 2012](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22156692/) — vessel wall MRI distinguishing RCVS from vasculitis

evidence.recommendation: PRES overlap occurs in 10-40% of RCVS patients
evidence.source: [Singhal et al. Neurology 2011](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21601163/) — RCVS clinical and radiographic spectrum

evidence.recommendation: Ischemic stroke complicates 10-40% of RCVS, typically watershed distribution
evidence.source: [Ducros et al. Stroke 2010](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20884871/)

evidence.recommendation: Transcranial Doppler for non-invasive monitoring of vasoconstriction
evidence.source: [Chen et al. Ann Neurol 2011](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21796667/) — TCD changes correlate with angiographic findings

evidence.recommendation: Postpartum angiopathy is a recognized RCVS variant
evidence.source: [Fugate et al. Stroke 2012](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22223244/) — postpartum cerebral angiopathy and RCVS

evidence.recommendation: Intra-arterial vasodilators for refractory RCVS with progressive ischemia
evidence.source: [Elstner et al. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 2009](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20035503/) — case series of endovascular rescue

evidence.recommendation: Avoid glucocorticoids in uncomplicated RCVS (may worsen outcomes; risk of misdiagnosis)
evidence.source: [Singhal et al. Neurology 2017](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/27940651/) — glucocorticoid use associated with worse outcomes in RCVS

evidence.recommendation: Recurrence rate of RCVS is low (~5-8%)
evidence.source: [Topcuoglu et al. Stroke 2017](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29321703/) — recurrence and long-term prognosis

evidence.recommendation: Blood pressure management: avoid both severe hypertension and aggressive lowering
evidence.source: Expert consensus; [Ducros & Bousser. Lancet Neurol 2012](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22995694/)

evidence.recommendation: Cannabis is an emerging common trigger for RCVS
evidence.source: [Wolff et al. Cerebrovasc Dis 2015](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25547150/) — cannabis-associated RCVS; systematic review

evidence.recommendation: RCVS diagnostic criteria and proposed scoring system
evidence.source: [Rocha et al. Stroke 2019](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31203787/) — RCVS2 score for clinical diagnosis

monitoring.frequency: Continuous in ICU/ED; q1h on floor x 24h, then q4h; each outpatient visit
monitoring.action: Titrate antihypertensives; avoid precipitous drops; raise if vasospasm-related ischemia

monitoring.frequency: q1h x 24h; then q2h x 48h; then q4h; each outpatient visit
monitoring.action: New deficit: STAT CT/CTA (stroke complication); reassess treatment; consider endovascular rescue

monitoring.frequency: Continuous telemetry x 48-72h on CCB; each visit on CCB
monitoring.action: Hold CCB if HR <50 or new AV block; ECG; cardiology if needed

monitoring.frequency: Baseline; 48-72h after CCB initiation; with each dose escalation; q2-4 weeks outpatient on verapamil
monitoring.action: Reduce or hold verapamil if PR prolongation >200 ms or new heart block

monitoring.frequency: Daily (inpatient); each visit (outpatient). Use numeric rating scale (0-10)
monitoring.action: New thunderclap headache: STAT vascular imaging (CTA/MRA) to assess vasoconstriction; escalate therapy

monitoring.frequency: Daily x 72h; then q48h; if cerebral edema or SIADH concern
At baseline; q48h inpatient; at each outpatient visit on NSAIDs
monitoring.action: Adjust medications; hold NSAIDs if declining

monitoring.frequency: At 4-6 weeks (interim); at 8-12 weeks (confirmatory); consider earlier if worsening
monitoring.action: If no resolution by 12 weeks: reconsider diagnosis (PACNS?); consider biopsy; extend CCB therapy

monitoring.frequency: Every 3-5 days inpatient; q2-4 weeks outpatient
monitoring.action: Increasing velocities suggest worsening vasoconstriction; consider escalating therapy

monitoring.frequency: Clinical observation; continuous EEG if altered consciousness or PRES overlap
monitoring.action: If seizure: levetiracetam; continuous EEG; MRI to assess for PRES or infarct

disposition.criteria: Generally NOT recommended from ED on initial presentation; RCVS requires inpatient observation to monitor for stroke complications (SAH, ischemic stroke) which may develop over days. Exception: stable patient with mild symptoms, confirmed diagnosis from prior admission, and close neurology follow-up within 48-72 hours
Thunderclap headache with imaging consistent with RCVS; no evidence of ischemic stroke, significant SAH, or PRES; hemodynamically stable; able to take oral medications; no ICU-level monitoring needs

Ischemic stroke complication; significant convexity SAH; PRES with seizures or encephalopathy; need for IV antihypertensives or IV CCB; hemodynamic instability; progressive neurologic deficits; need for endovascular intervention

disposition.disposition: Transfer to higher level of care
